thread.title: Big plays in overtime lift SJSU past UNLV
thread.title_full: Big plays in overtime lift SJSU past UNLV

author:
Willie Ramirez

Correspondent
title: Big plays in overtime lift SJSU past UNLV
text:
Big plays in overtime lift SJSU past UNLV By Willie Ramirez Posted: 10/10/2015 09:51:47 PM PDT Updated: 10/10/2015 09:51:50 PM PDT LAS VEGAS -- In a wild finish Saturday night, San Jose State survived a scare against UNLV, escaping with a 33-27 overtime victory. 
After Spartans defensive end Isaiah Irving blocked UNLV's Nicolai Bornand's 43-yard field-goal attempt on the first overtime series, SJSU quickly moved through the Rebels on its first drive in the extra period, culminating with Tyler Ervin's two-yard touchdown run. 
San Jose State improved to 3-3 overall and 2-1 in Mountain West play, while the Rebels dropped to 2-4 and 1-1 in league games. 
The win was San Jose's sixth straight against the Rebels, while the loss snapped UNLV's five-year win streak in conference home openers. 
The victory didn't come easy, however, as the Spartans squandered a 10-point lead in the fourth quarter, and needed a late drive to get back in the game. 
Trailing 24-20 with less than four minutes remaining, the Spartans drove 75 yards in nine plays, as quarterback Kenny Potter connected with Ervin for a 21-yard touchdown with 1:08 left. 
UNLV responded by driving 43 yards in nine plays, as Bornand booted a 49-yard field goal with 11 seconds left. 
Potter, who missed the previous two games because of an ankle injury, was 30 of 48 for 329 yards, two touchdowns and one interception. 
Ervin entered the game second in the nation in rushing, averaging 160.2 yards per game, struggled early. But he came up bid down the stretch and finished with 73 yards on 18 attempts and a touchdown, and caught eight passes for 74 yards. Advertisement 
After completing 5 of 10 passes for 26 yards with no touchdowns and an interception in the first quarter, Potter turned things around in the second quarter, completing 10 of 15 attempts for 142 yards with a touchdown and no interceptions to ignite the comeback. 
It wasn't until midway through the second quarter that San Jose was able to get in a groove, as Potter settled down to complete 6 of 8 pass attempts for 59 yards, including two key third-down conversions, on its first drive of the quarter. 
The drive ended with a 30-yard field goal by Austin Lopez, and the Spartans got the ball right back when Maurice McKnight intercepted UNLV's Kurt Palendech, and raced 54 yards to UNLV's 11-yard line. One play later, Potter hit Billy Freeman on a screen pass to his left, and Freeman rumbled in behind his blockers, as the Spartans tied the game, 10-10. 
The Spartans defense came up big again, forcing the Rebels out in three plays, and Potter went right back to work. The drive was highlighted by a 42-yard completion to Tyler Winston, his longest reception of the season, and culminated when Potter ran it in from 20 yards out to give the Spartans a 17-10 lead.
